title.content-text: 9.5.1 - Determining if an ACL is the Issue

brief.content-text:
The diagram depicts the output when examining an ACL on a network.

Network Topology
Two hosts with the following IP addresses, 192.168.1.2 and 192.168.1.3 are on the 192.168.1.0 /24 network. A switch is connected to the R1 F A 0 /0. This interface has an ACL applied (ACL 123 inbound). Router, R1, S0/0/0 is connected to the S0/0/0 of router, R2, with a of network address 172.20.0.1 /30. The R2 F A 0 /0 is connected to another switch with a network address of 192.168.2.0 /24. A server is connected to the switch with an IP address of 192.168.2.2. The configuration commands for placing the ACL are listed below.

Output
R1 (config)# access-list 123 deny tcp host 192.168.1.2 host 192.168.2.2 eq 23 log
R1 (config)# access-list 123 permit IP 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255 any log
R1 (config)# access-list 123 deny IP any any log
R1 (config)# int FA0/0
R1 (config-if)# IP access-group 123 In

ACL Console Logging
*Sep 12:34:35:54.067: *SEC - 6 -IPACCESSLOGP: list 123 denied tcp 192.168.1.2(1141) 192.168.2.2(23), 1 packet
R1#
*Sep 12:34:35:54.067: *SEC - 6 -IPACCESSLOGP: list 123 permitted icmp 192.168.1.3 192.168.2.2 (8 /0), 1 packet
